questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with severe burns on his body sustained in a house fire about an hour ago. His left lower leg was trapped under a burning beam, and as a result, he could not immediately escape from the house. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/55 mmHg. He is conscious but is moaning in pain. There is no singed hair on his face or nostrils, and he is breathing spontaneously. Physical examination shows 2nd-degree burns to the anterior chest, abdomen, and entire left leg. Which of the following most likely represents the total percentage of his whole body surface area involved in the burn according to the rule of nines?
questions.solution:
This patient has sustained 2nd-degree burns on different parts of his body (anterior chest and abdomen, left leg) after being trapped in a house fire. His vitals are unstable (increased body temperature, tachycardia, hypotension) due to fluid loss through the damaged skin and widespread cytokine activation. He needs urgent medical attention to avoid possible complications (e.g., infection, lactic acidosis) and death.

Management of burn patients (e.g., fluid resuscitation, antibiotics) depends on the severity of the burns and the total body surface area (TBSA) involved. Different methods are employed to assess the TBSA of a patient with burns (e.g., Lund-Browder charting, Palm method, etc.). One such method is known as the “Rule of Nines.” It is one of the most expeditious methods to estimate TBSA in adults. It attributes 9% of the TBSA to each of the following areas: head, anterior chest, posterior chest, anterior abdomen, posterior abdomen, right arm, left arm, and anterior and posterior parts of the right and left legs each. The perineum is assigned 1% of the TBSA. Therefore in the above patient, his anterior chest (9%) and abdomen (9%), together with anterior (9%) and posterior (9%) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% (9+9+9+9) involvement of the TBSA.  



Option Analysis

❌ 27%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9=36%)  
✅ 36%  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 45%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)  
❌ 54%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)  
❌ 63%  :
Incorrect: Following the rule of 9's, this patient’s anterior chest (9% of TBSA) and abdomen (9% of TBSA), together with anterior (9% of TBSA) and posterior (9% of TBSA) parts of the left leg, constitute 36% involvement of the TBSA (9+9+9+9= 36%)

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate diffuse skin blistering. Around four days ago, the patient developed fevers, muscle aches, and malaise. He attributed the symptoms to a viral infection. This morning, he noticed multiple bullae on his skin all over his body. He has also experienced ulceration and desquamation of the lips and oropharynx, which has made it difficult for him to eat or drink. The patient has recently been prescribed trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for cellulitis and acetaminophen to treat an ankle sprain. He has been taking lamotrigine for seizure prevention for the past ten years. He received a tetanus booster shot one week ago. Temperature is 39.2°C (103°F), blood pressure is 153/82 mmHg, and pulse is 93/min. Physical examination reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Painful lesions are present over 5% of the patient’s skin. Which of the following factors most likely precipitated this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with painful skin bullae and ulcerations, along with desquamation of mucosal surfaces. Given 5% of the patient’s skin is involved, his presentation is most consistent with Stevens-Johnsons syndrome (SJS). Of note, if skin involvement had exceeded 30%, the patient would have been diagnosed with toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).

SJS and TEN are characterized by painful vesicles/bullae on the skin along with ulceration of mucosal membranes. SJS/TEN most often results from an adverse reaction to medications. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is most commonly implicated in SJS/TEN and is the underlying cause of around 26% of cases in the United States. Other medications that may trigger SJS/TEN include ꞵ-lactam antibiotics, anticonvulsants (e.g., lamotrigine, phenytoin), allopurinol, and NSAIDs.

Less commonly, SJS/TEN can arise after infection by pathogens such as Mycoplasma pneumoniae and herpes simplex virus.  



Option Analysis

❌ Tetanus booster vaccination  :
Incorrect: Vaccinations are a rare and highly debatable cause of Stevens-Johnsons syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Instead, medications cause almost 90% of SJS/TEN cases in the United States.  
✅ Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole use  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acetaminophen use  :
Incorrect: Acetaminophen is an unlikely cause of SJS/TEN and is not commonly implicated. Another component of this patient’s history places him at greater risk for developing SJS/TEN.  
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection  :
Incorrect: Patients with SJS/TEN may have a prodromal phase characterized by non-specific, flu-like symptoms such as fever, malaise, cough, and myalgias. However, viral infections are a rare and poorly-documented cause of SJS/TEN.  
❌ Lamotrigine use  :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine is an anticonvulsant associated with around 9% of SJS/TEN cases. Most cases of SJS/TEN occur during the first eight weeks of therapy, making it unlikely for this patient who has been taking it for many years. Additionally, antibiotics (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, ꞵ-lactams) are more commonly implicated as the underlying cause of SJS/TEN.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the office because of worsening acne.  She has had multiple bouts of acne affecting her shoulders, chest, and face. The acne was treated with topical benzoyl peroxide and oral antibiotics with a slight improvement over the past three months. She is concerned because recently, her acneiform lesions have increased in size, transforming into nodules, thereby affecting her appearance. The patient immigrated from India with her family ten years ago. Past medical history is noncontributory. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and uses condoms consistently. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. After performing a complete physical examination, a decision to start oral isotretinoin is made. Which of the following laboratory investigations should be performed before initiating this drug?
questions.solution:
Acne vulgaris, an inflammatory skin condition with multifactorial etiology (follicular hyperkeratinization, increased sebum production, and infection by Cutibacterium acnes), can present with inflammatory papules, pustules, or nodules. Treatment options depend on the severity and include retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics, and isotretinoin.  

This patient suffering from nodulocystic acne needs treatment with oral isotretinoin. Isotretinoin is a known teratogen, and pregnancy should be actively ruled out by measuring serum or urine beta-hCG levels twice. Sexually active patients should be started on two different types of contraception before its initiation. Other standard pretreatment tests include a liver function test and lipid panel (serum triglyceride and cholesterol levels).  

Isotretinoin, a retinoid, is a last resort for treating severe (nodulocystic acne with scarring) or unresponsive acne vulgaris. It acts by shrinking the sebaceous glands (reducing sebum production), inhibiting the growth of Cutibacterium acnes, and preventing the formation of comedones. It has several adverse effects, including teratogenicity (craniofacial, cardiac, thymic, and central nervous system malformations), cheilitis, xerosis, conjunctivitis, pruritus, photosensitivity, and hypertriglyceridemia. It can also cause decreased bone mineral density, hepatotoxicity, fatigue, and lethargy.

Option Analysis

❌ Pulmonary function test:
Incorrect: Baseline pulmonary function testing is recommended before the initiation of amiodarone as it has a high tendency to cause pulmonary toxicity. Isotretinoin is not reported to affect the lung parenchyma. 
✅ Urine ꞵ-hCG test :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eye examination:
Incorrect: Hydroxychloroquine, a medication used to treat systemic lupus erythematosus, is typically a well-tolerated and safe drug; however, there is a small risk of retinal toxicity in patients with prolonged use. Therefore, patients should have a baseline ophthalmologic evaluation with periodic assessment.   
❌ International normalized ratio:
Incorrect: A baseline international normalized ratio (INR) should be obtained prior to warfarin administration to monitor its activity and prevent unwanted bleeding diathesis. Isotretinoin does not affect INR level.  
❌ Purified protein derivative test:
Incorrect: A purified protein derivative (PPD) test is recommended before administering immunosuppressive drugs like infliximab, an anti-TNF agent, to prevent the reactivation of underlying latent tuberculosis. Isotretinoin does not compromise the immune system.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of acne. He has had acne for several years but noticed it has worsened in the past few months. He has tried an over-the-counter benzoyl peroxide wash and topical retinoid cream without improvement. He has multiple bright red pustules and acneiform papules on the forehead and cheeks on physical examination. He was prescribed doxycycline for three months, which leads to symptomatic improvement. However, after six months, the patient’s symptoms worsened. What is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to this class of antibiotics?

choices.text: Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala

questions.solution:
Doxycycline and other tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics that inhibit the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome, thereby preventing attachment of aminoacyl-tRNA. Doxycycline is commonly used in the treatment of acne vulgaris.

Bacteria can develop resistance to tetracyclines primarily by forming plasmid-encoded transport pumps that decrease the uptake or increase the efflux of tetracyclines out of the cell. Other proposed resistance mechanisms include ribosomal protection and bacterial modification of tetracycline molecules, reducing the drug’s effectiveness.  

Option Analysis

✅ Plasmid-encoded transport pumps  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Bacterial transferase enzymes:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to aminoglycoside antibiotics (e.g., gentamicin, neomycin, amikacin, tobramycin, streptomycin). These enzymes inactive the drugs through adenylation, phosphorylation, or acetylation.  
❌ Carbapenemases:
Incorrect: This is how bacteria develop resistance to carbapenems (e.g., doripenem, imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem). These antibiotics are not used in the routine treatment of acne vulgaris.  
❌ Amino acid modification of D-Ala D-Ala:
Incorrect: This is the mechanism by which bacteria develop resistance to vancomycin. D-Ala D-Ala is converted to D-Ala D-Lac, preventing vancomycin from binding to the bacterial cell wall.  
❌ Methylation of 23S rRNA-binding site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes how bacteria develop resistance to macrolide antibiotics. Methylation of the site prevents the binding of drug molecules to the ribosome.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of a rash on his chest. The patient had a burning pain across his right chest last week, followed by the eruption of painful blisters two days ago. The patient has a history of a kidney transplant due to underlying diabetes and hypertension. The patient is currently taking tacrolimus daily. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 156/65 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for the finding as shown. Which of the following pathogens is most likely implicated in this patient’s clinical condition?

Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with herpes zoster or shingles, as manifested by the small clustered vesicular lesions in the T3 dermatome across the right chest that do not cross the midline. The organism known to induce this dermatologic finding is human-herpesvirus 3 (HHV-3).   

Shingles refers to the reactivation of a latent infection with the varicella-zoster virus, or HHV-3 – the same pathogen associated with childhood chickenpox. After the primary infection has subsided, the virus remains latent in the dorsal root or trigeminal nerve ganglia, typically for decades. Without proper vaccination, the virus harbors the risk of reactivation (especially in immunocompromised patients) within the ganglion to involve multiple sensory neurons and spread down the sensory nerve to establish infection in the skin.  

Clinically, this condition manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome or several contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles, which become pustular. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in post-herpetic neuralgia, the most common complication of shingles.    

Most commonly, reactivation occurs on the trunk; however, when reactivation occurs in the distribution of trigeminal V1, ocular involvement may occur. In this case, patients may also experience hearing loss, facial paralysis, or loss of taste, known as Ramsay-hunt syndrome. Less common complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varicella-zoster virus (Human-herpes-virus 3) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect:  Staphylococcus aureus is a well-established cause of purulent cellulitis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Epstein Barr virus:
Incorrect:  The Epstein Barr virus, also known as HHV-4, is the most common culprit implicated in the setting of infectious mononucleosis; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Human-herpes-virus 6:
Incorrect: Human herpesvirus 6 is the pathogen most commonly associated with roseola infantum in children, which typically presents with a few days of high-grade fever followed by the eruption of a blanching maculopapular rash. This patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.  
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus is the most common etiology of infectious mononucleosis in heterophile-negative patients; however, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with varicella-zoster given the findings of rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single dermatome.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of joint pain and stiffness. The patient reports bilateral pain of her hand, wrist and knee joints for the past 10 days. The symptoms are worse in the morning and get better with movement. The patient has had no associated chills, fever or rash. Past medical history is significant for hereditary spherocytosis. Family history is significant for gout in the patient’s father.  The patient is a school teacher and does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows mild swelling with no redness, warmth or tenderness of the affected joints. Oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable. X-ray of both hands is normal. Considering the most likely cause of this patient’s condition, she is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s acute symmetric arthropathy with normal x-ray is consistent with parvovirus B19 infection. Her history of hereditary spherocytosis puts her at increased risk of having transient aplastic crisis.   

Parvovirus B19 causes erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) in children and arthritis in adults. It is primarily transmitted by respiratory droplets and replicates in erythroid progenitors in the bone marrow. Parvovirus B19 binds the P antigen on proerythroblasts’ cell membranes. Viral replication in the nucleus leads to cell lysis, which can cause transient aplastic crisis (TAC), in which the temporary suspension of erythropoiesis leads to severe anemia and related complications. This complication usually occurs in individuals with hematologic abnormalities, including increased RBC destruction (e.g., sickle cell disease, hereditary spherocytosis) or decreased RBC production (e.g., iron deficiency anemia, thalasemia).  

Parvovirus B19 in a pregnant female can interrupt erythropoiesis in the fetus, causing profound anemia,  congestive heart failure, and pleural and pericardial effusions (hydrops fetalis).

Option Analysis

✅ Transient aplastic crisis:
 Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Coronary artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: Coronary artery aneurysm is a life-threatening complication of Kawasaki disease. Such patients usually present with fever, strawberry tongue, a rash, lymphadenopathy and bilateral conjunctival injection. This patient’s joint pain is likely secondary to parvovirus B19 infection.
❌ Encephalitis:
Incorrect:  Measles is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis that is followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash spreading in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles). In the absence of a rash and a flu-like prodrome, measles is unlikely.
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is a known complication of acute group A streptococcal infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure, along with fever and gray white pharyngeal exudates. This patient’s oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable. 
❌ Orchitis:
Incorrect: Orchitis is a common complication of mumps. Patients usually present with fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of a rash. Two days ago, the patient developed fever, malaise and loss of appetite, which was followed by the appearance of multiple small “fluid filled bumps” on his trunk and face. Last night, the parents noticed a similar rash on his extremities. The rash is intensely pruritic, to the extent that the patient is unable to sleep at night. The patient has not received any vaccines since birth due to parental preference and does not have any medical conditions. He regularly goes to a community school. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination is shown.
 

Reproduced by WIkipedia

The oropharyngeal examination is within normal limits. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?

choices.text: Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules
Eye redness, pain and blurred vision

questions.solution:
This child’s presentation is consistent varicella (chickenpox) which is caused by varicella zoster virus (VZV), a double-stranded DNA virus in the family Herpesviridae. Acute cerebellar ataxia is a known complication of VZV infection that can present with sudden, uncoordinated muscle movements.  

Chickenpox is highly contagious, and transmission occurs in susceptible hosts via contact with aerosolized droplets from nasopharyngeal secretions of an infected individual or by direct cutaneous contact with vesicle fluid from skin lesions. Patients present with fever, malaise, and a rash characterized by macules, papules, vesicles, and scabs. The patient with varicella typically has lesions in different stages of development on the face, trunk and extremities.The skin lesions are small with an erythematous base of 5–10 mm and appear in successive crops over 2–4 days.  

Varicella, generally, is a self-limited infection and does not require antiviral therapy. In rare cases, patients are susceptible to a number of complications, including invasive group A streptococcal soft tissue infection, acute cerebellar ataxia, encephalitis and pneumonia. 

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden, uncoordinated muscle movements:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Pale skin, fatigue and weakness:
Incorrect: Pale skin, fatigue and weakness are suggestive of aplastic anemia, which is a potential complication of parvovirus B19 infection (erythema infectiosum).  It begins with a minor febrile prodrome followed by the typical “slapped cheek” rash several days later that may spread as a lacy reticular rash all over the body. An intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox.
❌ Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules:
Incorrect: Painful tender joints and subcutaneous nodules are suggestive of acute rheumatic fever, which is a potential complication of group A Streptococcus infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure along with fever, malaise and pharyngitis. This patient’s oropharyngeal examination is unremarkable.
❌ Eye redness, pain and blurred vision:
Incorrect: Eye redness, pain and blurred vision is indicative of keratitis and can be seen in herpes simplex virus infection.  This patient’s intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox, which is caused by varicella zoster virus.
❌ Severe testicular pain and swelling:
Incorrect: Severe testicular pain and swelling is suggestive of orchitis, a potential complication of mumps. It is characterized by fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours. An intensely pruritic vesiculopapular rash in different stages is typical of chicken pox.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old female newborn is currently being evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of a rash, fever, and poor feeding. The patient was born full term to a mother taking lamotrigine for seizure prophylaxis. Birth history was otherwise uncomplicated. On day 2 of life, the patient developed macular erythema in the skin folds that progressed to flaccid bullae with thick crusting on days 3 and 4. No mucosal membrane involvement was observed. Vitals are significant for a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9°F). A depiction of the current state of the rash is shown below:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This neonate presents with a diffuse macular rash with bullae formation followed by exfoliation of the skin. These findings are most consistent with staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS).

SSSS is caused by infection with Staphylococcus aureus strains carrying exfoliative toxin A and/or B. Exfoliative toxins A and B cleave desmoglein 1, which is a protein responsible for attachment between keratinocytes in the superficial epidermis. This presentation is in contrast to that of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), wherein the epidermal-dermal junctions are destroyed and mucosal membrane involvement is present.

Clinically, SSSS begins as a macular erythematous rash in the skin folds that rapidly progresses to flaccid bullae. These bullae will rupture and subsequently cause skin crusting with desquamation of the epidermis. Associated clinical findings include fevers, irritability, and poor feeding. The majority of cases occur in neonates and children. However, adult cases have been reported, particularly in those with underlying renal impairment. It is thought that the toxin is not secreted by the kidneys properly, and thus accumulates and causes the skin manifestations.

Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Toxic epidermal necrolysis:
Incorrect: Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) represents a more severe form of Stevens Johnson syndrome. TEN is characterized by fever, bullae formation, necrosis, and sloughing of skin at the dermal-epidermal junction. Medications, in particular anticonvulsants, are a common precipitating factor. However, unlike staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome, TEN also involves the mucous membranes.
❌ Kawasaki disease:
Incorrect: Kawasaki disease tends to present with a diffuse, macular-papular, erythematous rash. It would not present with an exfoliating rash. Furthermore, patients with Kawasaki disease tend to have conjunctival injection as well as swelling and erythema of the tongue.
❌ Scarlet fever:
Incorrect: Scarlet fever refers to a constellation of symptoms due Streptococcus pyogenes pharyngitis that includes sore throat, fever, lymphadenopathy, and a diffuse erythematous rash that has a “sand-paper like” texture. In contrast, scarlet fever would not present with the bullae and skin swelling observed in this patient.
❌ Bullous impetigo:
Incorrect: Bullous impetigo is a sequelae of Staphylococcus aureus infection that results in the formation of large bullae. These bullae eventually burst, leaving behind a characteristic golden crusting lesion. In contrast, this patient has a diffuse, exfoliating rash that is more consistent with the presentation of staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a high-grade fever and a rash for the past 2 days. The rash first appeared on his face and has now spread over his entire body. Prior to the onset of the rash, the patient had a cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes. He has not received any vaccinations due to parental preference. The rest of the history is noncontributory. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 31/min and blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tired and restless child with a diffuse, erythematous, maculopapular rash all over the body sparing the palms and soles. Oral examination shows tiny, white round lesions on the buccal mucosa. No pharyngeal exudates are seen. The patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with measles (rubeola), which is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots and a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing the palms and soles).  

Measles affects various organs and can lead to complications such as pneumonia, diarrhea, and, on rare occasions, acute encephalitis, all of which can lead to death. In addition, it can suppress the immune system for up to 6 weeks, contributing to bacterial superinfections (e.g., otitis media and bacterial pneumonia). Pneumonia is the most common cause of measles-associated death in children.  

Another severe and often fatal complication for children under 2 years old is the development of subacutesclerosing panencephalitis, which can happen 7-10 years later. It can lead to dementia, spasticity, epilepsy, and autonomic dysfunction. This complication is thought to be caused by a persistent measles virus infection, possibly due to an abnormal immune response or a mutated strain of the measles virus, which leads to chronic inflammation of the entire brain. Immunocompromised patients have higher rates of pneumonia and encephalitis, which contribute to a higher mortality rate. 

Option Analysis

❌ Aplastic anemia:
Incorrect: Aplastic anemia can complicate parvovirus B19 infection in patients with sickle cell anemia or immunosuppression. Measles does not usually cause or increase the risk of aplastic crises.  
❌ Coronary artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: Coronary artery aneurysm is a life-threatening complication of Kawasaki disease. Such patients usually present with fever, strawberry tongue, a rash, lymphadenopathy and bilateral conjunctival injection. Koplick spots seen in this patient, however, are pathognomonic of measles. 
✅ Encephalitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Rheumatic fever is a known complication of acute group A streptococcal infection, which can cause scarlet fever and pharyngitis. Patients typically present with a sandpaper-like rash that blanches with pressure along with fever, malaise and gray white pharyngeal exudates. The presence of Koplik spots in this patient is suggestive of measles.
❌ Orchitis:
Incorrect: Orchitis is a common complication of mumps. Patients usually present with fever, malaise and myalgias followed by the development of parotitis within 48 hours. A maculopapular rash is typically absent.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider for evaluation of painful lesions on the forehead. The lesions appeared approximately one week ago and started off as small fluid filled sacs. Over the past few days, the lesions have become more red and painful. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and asthma. She does not consume tobacco or alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

If untreated, this patient is at highest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient has unilateral erythema and vesicular lesions in the V1 distribution, which is concerning for herpes zoster (also termed shingles). Given the distribution of these lesions, lack of treatment may result in herpes zoster ophthalmicus, keratitis, and subsequent blindness.

Shingles is due to reactivation of latent varicella zoster virus (VZV), which is the virus responsible for chickenpox in children. After the initial chickenpox has resolved, VZV remains latent in the dorsal root ganglia or sensory ganglia of cranial nerves and is subject to reactivation. During reactivation, the virus replicates and spreads within the ganglion to involve sensory neurons and spreads antegrade along the sensory nerve to cause cutaneous infection.

Clinically, shingles manifests with a rash that starts as erythematous papules in a single or multiple contiguous dermatomes. Over the next several days, the rash develops into small vesicles. As this process occurs, the involved sensory ganglion exhibits intense inflammation and hemorrhagic necrosis of nerve cells, resulting in the most common complication of post-herpetic neuralgia.

Specific complications depend on the dermatome involved. When reactivation occurs in the V1 distribution, ocular involvement may occur. If cranial VII is involved, patients may experience Ramsay Hunt syndrome, which is characterized by the triad of hearing loss, facial paralysis, and vesicles in the auditory canal and auricle. Rarer complications include meningitis, encephalitis, myelitis, or bacterial superinfection in immunocompromised hosts.  

Option Analysis

✅ Keratitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Meningitis:
Incorrect: Meningitis is a known complication of shingles; however, it is a less common complication. This patient is at higher risk of keratitis, and potentially blindness, given the proximity of the lesions to her eye.
❌ Squamous cell carcinoma:
Incorrect: Actinic keratoses are premalignant lesions that have a rough, sandpaper-like appearance. If untreated, actinic keratosis can lead to squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). However, this patient has multiple vesicular lesions that are consistent with the presentation of herpes zoster, which is not associated with SCC.
❌ Cavernous sinus thrombosis:
Incorrect: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not a well-established complication of herpes zoster. It is more commonly implicated in chronic bacterial sinus infections and hypercoagulable states.
❌ Unilateral facial paralysis:
Incorrect: Bell palsy may occur if there is reactivation of the varicella zoster virus in the cranial nerve VII distribution. Patients with cranial nerve VII involvement will likely have lesions in the auditory canal or external ear. In contrast, this patient’s vesicular lesions are located on the forehead, which is more consistent with a cranial nerve V in the V1 branch distribution.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of a rash. She reports that yesterday, a rash appeared on his face that has now spread over his entire body. The patient has also been having cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes for the past 3-4 days. The patient lives with his parents and 2 cats. He has not received vaccinations due to parental preference. Approximately 2 weeks ago, the patient returned from a trip to the Philippines after visiting his grandparents. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min and blood pressure is 110/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows a tired and restless child. The patient has a diffuse erythematous maculopapular rash all over the body except the palms and soles. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.  Which of the following is most commonly associated with this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of flu-like symptoms (cough, rhinorrhea and pink eyes), followed by high grade fever and maculopapular rash, is consistent with measles (rubeola), most likely due to the lack of childhood vaccination.  

Measles is a highly contagious viral disease caused by the “measles virus,” of the family Paramyxoviridae. It spreads by respiratory droplets which can remain airborne for several hours in a closed space (e.g., schools, physicians’ offices, etc.). It can also spread via direct contact of respiratory particles with a mucosal surface. Non-immunized patients are at high-risk. The incubation period is ~10 days to fever onset and 14 days to rash onset.  

Clinically, it is characterized by a prodromal illness of fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by Koplik spots (small white spots on the inside of the cheeks opposite the molars). After 2-4 days, a red, blotchy, maculopapular rash appears and spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing palms and soles).


Reproduced from wikipedia

The rash then coalesces and may develop into a non blanching dark reddish brown rash. It usually fades after 4 days, leading into the recovery phase which can last for another 10-14 days, with the final symptom usually being a persistent cough. Recovered patients develop life-long immunity.  

Short term complications associated with measles include pneumonia, diarrhea, and acute encephalitis. Pneumonia is the most common cause of measles-associated death in children. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis is a rare complication that appears several years after apparent recovery from initial infection.


Option Analysis

❌ Ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products:
Incorrect: Ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products is associated with Salmonella, E. coli, Listeria, Campylobacter and other foodborne organisms. Patients usually present with diarrhea, fever, and stomach cramps. In this case, a maculopapular rash following a viral prodrome is suggestive of measles.
❌ Chronic exposure to cat feces:
Incorrect: Chronic exposure to cat feces is associated with the development of Toxoplasma gondii. The patients usually present with mononucleosis-like symptoms (pharyngitis and lymphadenopathy). In immunocompromised patients, it may progress to cause brain abscesses, which are seen as multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI. A maculopapular rash following a viral prodrome is instead suggestive of measles.
✅ Lack of childhood vaccinations:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Vitamin A deficiency:
Incorrect: Although vitamin A supplementation has been shown to improve mortality in patients with measles, its deficiency does not predispose to the development of the illness.
❌ Tick bite:
Incorrect: Lyme disease caused by Borrelia burgdorferi is transmitted by the Ixodes deer tick. It is common in the northeastern United States. Patients initially present with erythema migrans (typical “bulls-eye” configuration) and flu-like symptoms, which may be followed by facial nerve palsy (typically bilateral), arthritis and heart block.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician for evaluation of skin lesions. The patient’s mother noticed several bumpy skin lesions on her daughter's arm earlier this week. The patient is currently attending daycare and scraped her knee last week but is otherwise healthy. She has not been exposed to any sick contacts, and none of her family members have similar lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the following finding:

 
Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

These lesions are nontender to palpation. The pathogen responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation was most likely transmitted in which of the following manners?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with umbilicated papules that are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum. The condition is caused by the molluscum contagiosum virus, which is transmitted via direct contact (e.g, skin to skin contact, fomite to skin contact).

The molluscum contagiosum virus is a DNA poxvirus that generates characteristic skin lesions, most commonly in pediatric patients. These lesions are identified by skin-coloured, dome-shaped papules that average 3-5 mm in diameter and have an area of central umbilication. The lesions are painless and non-tender to palpation. Molluscum contagiosum lesions are most commonly found on the trunk, but they can also be found on the extremities and face.

The presence of molluscum contagiosum papules on or near the groin should prompt concern for sexual transmission. In addition, recurrent or extensive lesions should prompt concern for underlying immunodeficiency (e.g. HIV infection).

Option Analysis

✅ Direct skin to skin transmission:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Respiratory droplets:
Incorrect: This patient has several painless lesions with central umbilication, which is concerning for molluscum contagiosum. It is spread via direct skin contact, not via respiratory droplets. Organisms transmitted via respiratory droplets include paramyxoviruses, orthomyxoviruses, and rhinovirus.
❌ Vector borne transmission:
Incorrect: The molluscum contagiosum virus is not a vector borne virus, meaning it is not transmitted through vectors such as mosquitos or ticks. In contrast, the West Nile virus is an example of a vector borne disease.
❌ Fecal-oral transmission:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is not transmitted via the fecal-oral route but rather direct skin to skin contact. Adenovirus and hepatitis A are examples of viruses transmitted via the fecal-oral route.
❌ Blood-borne transmission:
Incorrect: Molluscum contagiosum is not transmitted via blood borne transmission but rather direct skin to skin contact.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his parent for the evaluation of a diffuse rash. The parent reports that the boy had flushed cheeks for the past 2 days. Today in the morning, while dressing him up, she noticed a lace-like rash on his stomach, back and extremities. The patient had a low-grade fever, cough, and sore throat for the past 6 days. He goes to a daycare daily, and a number of children there have reported similar symptoms. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), which is caused by parvovirus B19 infection.   

Parvovirus B19 is part of the parvoviridae family and is a single-stranded DNA virus. It is primarily transmitted by respiratory droplets but transmission can also occur via an infected blood transfusion or from mother to baby through the placenta. It replicates primarily in erythroid progenitors.  

Erythema infectiosum most commonly affects children of early school age and occasionally adults. Infection begins with a minor febrile prodrome ~4–14 days after exposure, and the typical “slapped cheek” rash (relative circumoral pallor) develops several days later. After 2–3 days, the erythematous macular rash may spread to the extremities in a lacy reticular pattern.



Reproduced from Wikipedia

Joint involvement (due to immune complex deposition) is a prominent feature in adult cases. Joints in the hands and the knees are most frequently affected. The symptoms mimic rheumatoid arthritis, and the arthropathy may persist for weeks, months, or years.

Option Analysis

❌ Coxsackievirus:
Incorrect:  Coxsackievirus can cause hand-foot-mouth disease. The majority of patients develop small vesicles on the tongue or oral mucosa, which rapidly rupture to form shallow erosions. The cutaneous manifestations include bilateral macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash on palms and soles.
❌ Cytomegalovirus:
Incorrect: Cytomegalovirus typically presents with an infectious mononucleosis-like syndrome and is characterized by fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy.
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Cutaneous manifestations of streptococcus pyogenes infection (e.g. scarlet fever) include a sand-paper like rash along with pharyngitis. In children <3 years of age, it usually presents with nasal congestion, discharge, low-grade fever (e.g. <38.3°C [101°F]), and tender anterior cervical adenopathy.
✅ Parvovirus B19:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Human herpesvirus-6:
Incorrect: Roseola infantum is caused by Human Herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6) and classically presents with a fever for 3-5 days followed by a maculopapular rash.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician due to a facial rash. The rash started one week ago as a small vesicle and has enlarged. The rash is itchy and painful. Physical examination shows erythematous plaque with a honey-colored crust on the left maxilla. Culture is taken from the lesion and positive for group A streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes). The child is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?

choices.text: No increased risk of long-term complications

questions.solution:
This child has impetigo, a superficial skin infection characterized by an erythematous plaque with a honey-colored crust. Streptococcus pyogenes, also known as group A strep (GAS), is one of the causative agents of non-bullous impetigo.

GAS is a Gram-positive bacterium that can cause two types of infections: skin infections (e.g., impetigo, erysipelas, cellulitis) and pharyngitis. Infections with GAS can lead to severe sequelae, which are mainly immunological. The most feared sequelae are acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) and acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Patients with GAS skin infections are at increased risk of PSGN but not ARF. On the other hand, patients with GAS pharyngitis are at increased risk of both PSGN and ARF.

Option Analysis

✅ Glomerulonephritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mitral valve stenosis:
Incorrect: Mitral valve stenosis is a long-term complication of acute rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease. Acute rheumatic fever is a feared complication of pharyngitis caused by S. pyogenes but does not occur from the strains of S. pyogenes causing skin infections (e.g., impetigo).  
❌ Acute rheumatic fever:
Incorrect: Acute rheumatic fever is a feared complication of pharyngitis caused by S. pyogenes. However, acute rheumatic fever does not occur from the strains of S. pyogenes causing skin infections.  
❌ Recurrence of the infection:
Incorrect: There is no increased risk of recurrence of impetigo compared to the average population.  
❌ No increased risk of long-term complications:
Incorrect: Glomerulonephritis is a known possible complication of impetigo caused by S. pyogenes.

questions.text:
A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic due to a skin lesion. The lesion started as a small vesicle that continues to enlarge. It is not painful or itchy. The patient was stationed in the military in Iraq for the last 5 years and just returned to the United States 6 months ago. Examination of the lesion reveals a black necrotic lesion surrounded by edema as shown in the picture below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the edema surrounding this skin lesion?  


Source: Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts like adenylate cyclase
An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts as a protease
Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by macrophages
Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by T-cells
Increased vascular permeability due to the degranulation of mast cells in the local tissue

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has cutaneous anthrax caused by Bacillus anthracis, a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium. The spores of Bacillus anthracis are found in soil and mostly cause diseases in horses, cattle, and sheep. People who handle these animals can get an infection through skin contact (cutaneous anthrax), or by inhalation or ingestion (pulmonary or gastrointestinal anthrax, respectively) of contaminated products. Anthrax can also be used as a biological weapon.

Cutaneous anthrax is characterized by an edematous and painless black eschar. The lesion usually starts as a papule that converts into a large vesicle, then ruptures. The black color of the lesion is due to necrosis of the skin tissue. Upon skin contact, B. anthracis spores enter the skin. The spores are then taken up by macrophages where they convert to active bacteria and start producing toxins.

Anthrax toxin is an exotoxin complex, which is composed of a protective antigen, edema factor, and lethal factor. Protective antigen allows toxins to enter into immune cells. Edema factor acts like adenylate cyclase, increasing the production of cyclic adenosine monophosphate. This causes phagocytic dysfunction and is also responsible for the edema that surrounds the black eschar in cutaneous anthrax.
 

Lethal factor is a zinc-dependent protease that cleaves mitogen-dependent protein kinases which are used by the immune system and other cells in the body to produce NADPH. Without NADPH the cells cannot produce ATP, and eventually undergo apoptosis.  


Option Analysis

✅ An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts like adenylate cyclase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ An exotoxin produced by the bacteria that acts as a protease:
Incorrect: The lethal factor, which is one part of the anthrax toxin, acts as a protease. However, it is not responsible for the edema that surrounds the black eschar.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by macrophages:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to inflammatory cytokines released by T-cells:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.  
❌ Increased vascular permeability due to the degranulation of mast cells in the local tissue:
Incorrect: The edema that surrounds the black eschar in patients with cutaneous anthrax is most likely due to the edema factor of the anthrax toxins.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parent because of difficulty in feeding him for a day. The parent reports that the patient felt warm last night, but he did not have any chills, myalgia, cough or sneezing. Past medical history is unremarkable. The patient is up to date on his vaccinations. Temperature is 37.7°C (100°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 110/78 mmHg.  Physical examination shows a maculopapular and vesicular rash scattered on the palms and soles bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination shows superficial ulcers with a greyish-yellow base and an erythematous rim on the tongue and buccal mucosa. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with difficulty eating in combination with oral ulcers and bilateral maculopapular and vesicular rash on palm and soles, is consistent with hand-foot-mouth disease.  

Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a viral illness caused by enteroviruses, most commonly coxsackievirus. It is transmitted from person to person by the fecal-oral route. Children younger than 10 years of age are most frequently affected, and infected adults rarely show signs of infection. Patients usually present with mouth or throat pain and/or refusal to eat. Prodromal symptoms (e.g., chills, myalgia and rhinorrhea) are usually absent. The majority of patients develop small vesicles on the tongue or oral mucosa, which rapidly rupture to form shallow erosions. The cutaneous manifestations associated with HFMD include bilateral macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash, and all three lesions may occur in a single patient. It typically involves the hands (palms), feet (soles and heels), buttocks, legs (upper thighs), and arms. The rash is nonpruritic and nontender.  

HFMD is a clinical diagnosis, and management is typically supportive with attempts to reduce discomfort and dehydration.


Option Analysis

❌ Herpes simplex virus:
Incorrect: Herpes simplex virus type 1 can cause gingivostomatitis with a prodrome of prodrome of fever, anorexia, irritability, and headache before the appearance of oral lesions, which appear as a focal area of grouped vesicles with an erythematous base. Skin lesions (e.g. herpetic whitlow), if present, are unilateral (unlike this patient).
✅ Coxsackievirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Rickettsia rickettsii:
Incorrect: Rickettsia rickettsii is a tick that can cause Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever. Patients usually present with nonspecific signs (e.g., fever, myalgia and malaise) and a diffuse macular rash that starts on the ankle and wrist and spreads to the palm and soles and becomes petechial. Vesicular rash and oral lesions are atypical.
❌ Treponema pallidum:
Incorrect: Treponema pallidum can cause secondary syphilis, which usually presents with a maculopapular rash that involves the palm and soles. It does not evolve into a vesicular rash, and oral mucosa involvement is not seen.
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of erysipelas and cellulitis. Manifestations typically include skin erythema, edema and warmth. This patient’s presentation is suggestive of hand-foot-mouth disease.

questions.text:
An 11-month-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for the evaluation of a rash. The patient had a low-grade fever for the past 2 days which was controlled with acetaminophen. Last night, the patient developed a pink rash on her face that has spread to her body this morning. The patient does not have cough, rhinorrhea, vomiting or diarrhea. The rest of the history is unremarkable. The patient has not received any vaccinations since birth. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 27/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows small tender lymph nodes in the suboccipital and postauricular region. Oropharyngeal examination is within normal limits. The rash is shown in the image.  


Reproduced from Wikipedia

Which of the following best describes the agent responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This infant has fever, lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash -- findings that can be seen in rubella virus infection.   

The Rubella virus is a part of the Togaviridae family, which are single-strand RNA viruses surrounded by an icosahedral capsid. It spreads from person to person via respiratory droplets. Primary implantation and replication in the nasopharynx is followed by spread to the lymph nodes. Nonimmunized patients are at high-risk. Rubella infections (also known as 3-day German measles) are usually asymptomatic, but when there are symptoms, they typically show up after a 14 day incubation period. It is characterized by a maculopapular rash that first appears on the face and thereafter spreads in a cephalocaudal progression (sparing palms and soles) and usually lasts for up to 3 days.  



Reproduced from Wikipedia

Lymphadenopathy, particularly occipital and postauricular, may be noted during the second week after exposure. Some patients also have petechiae or erythematous papules, known as Forchheimer spots on the soft palate.  Although acquired rubella is usually thought of as a benign disease, arthralgia and arthritis are common in infected adults, particularly women. 

Option Analysis

❌ Enveloped double-stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Varicella zoster virus (VZV) and herpes simplex virus (HSV) are examples of enveloped double stranded DNA viruses. VZV can cause shingles and chickenpox, whereas HSV can manifest as gingivostomatitis or herpes genitalis. None of these present with a maculopapular rash or cause postauricular lymphadenopathy.
❌ Non-enveloped single stranded DNA virus:
Incorrect: Parvovirus is a non-enveloped single stranded DNA virus. In children, it causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which typically presents with a “slapped cheek” rash, followed by a lacy rash on the arms, legs, and trunk. Tender suboccipital and postauricular lymphadenopathy with a centrifugally spreading maculopapular rash is instead suggestive of rubella.
❌ Gram-positive cocci in chains:
Incorrect: Group A Streptococci appear as gram-positive cocci in chains and can clinically present with a sand-paper like rash in affected individuals along with pharyngitis. This patient’s maculopapular rash with centrifugal spread is instead suggestive of rubella.
✅ Enveloped single stranded RNA virus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Non-enveloped single stranded RNA virus:
Incorrect: Coxsackievirus is a non-enveloped single-stranded RNA virus which can cause hand-foot-mouth disease. The majority of patients develop small vesicles on the tongue or oral mucosa, which rapidly rupture to form shallow erosions. The cutaneous manifestations include bilateral macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash on palms and soles.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old young man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of lesions on the abdomen. The lesions were fluid-filled sacs that eventually burst, leaving behind yellow, crusted areas of inflammation. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. Physical examination is notable for the following finding:



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogenic factors is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient had flaccid bullae on the trunk that ruptured and left behind yellow, crusted lesions. These findings are consistent with bullous impetigo, which is most commonly caused by strains of Staphylococcus aureus that secrete exfoliative toxin A.

Impetigo is a contagious superficial bacterial infection manifesting on the face, trunk, and extremities with lesions that progress from papules to vesicles/bullae and later crusting. Impetigo is divided into bullous and non-bullous forms.

Non-bullous impetigo is the more common form and is caused by either Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Clinically, it is characterized by papules that progress to vesicles surrounded by erythema, which subsequently break down to form thick, adherent crusts with a characteristic golden appearance. It most commonly involves the face and extremities.

In contrast, bullous impetigo is less common and is almost always due to infection with Staphylococcus aureus strains carrying exfoliative toxin A. This toxin targets desmoglein, resulting in loss of adhesion along the superficial epidermis. Clinically, exfoliative toxin A leads to formation of large bullae that eventually burst and leave behind a golden crusting lesion. Bullous impetigo is nearly always found on the trunk.



Option Analysis

✅ Exfoliative toxin A :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Erythrogenic toxin:
Incorrect: Scarlet fever arises due to infection by Streptococcus pyogenes. The condition is characterized by a constellation of symptoms including fever, pharyngitis, strawberry tongue, and a diffuse erythematous rash. The pathogenic etiology of the scarlatiniform rash is streptococcal erythrogenic toxin.
❌ IgA protease:
Incorrect: IgA protease is a virulence factor that allows pathogens to adhere to mucous membranes. IgA protease is produced by several organisms including Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitidis, as well as Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is not, however, implicated in the pathogenesis of this patient’s bullous impetigo.
❌ Streptolysin O:
Incorrect: Streptolysin O is a virulence factor produced by Streptococcus pyogenes that induces beta hemolysis and cell membrane degradation. However, streptolysin O does not play a direct role in the pathogenesis of this patient’s bullous impetigo.
❌ Toxin B:
Incorrect: Toxin B is associated with Clostridium difficile infection and results in destabilization of the actin cytoskeleton. Clostridium difficile infection would manifest with watery diarrhea but not the cutaneous findings present in this patient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to severe shortness of breath and a cough with blood in the sputum. The patient started feeling tired and having myalgias a few days ago. The shortness of breath began yesterday and has worsened ever since. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol, and is employed on a horse farm. Chest X-ray demonstrates pulmonary infiltrates and a widened mediastinum. Sputum culture reveals a Gram-positive bacterium with a polypeptide capsule. Which of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient likely has pulmonary anthrax (also known as woolsorter disease). This is caused by Bacillus anthracis, a Gram-positive spore-forming bacterium. Pulmonary anthrax is a severe form of anthrax caused by inhalation of B. anthracis spores. Exposure is often from infected farm animals. Once in the lungs, the spores are taken up by macrophages and transported to the mediastinal lymph nodes, where they germinate, multiply and begin toxin production.

Pulmonary anthrax is the most severe form of anthrax. It is characterized by severe necrosis of the mediastinal lymph nodes and damage to the alveoli. On imaging, pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal widening are often seen. Patients develop shortness of breath, hemoptysis and high fever, and can eventually develop bacteremia and death. Due to the severity of pulmonary anthrax, it is a possible agent for bioterrorism.  


Option Analysis

✅ Bacillus anthracis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae:
Incorrect: S. pneumoniae has a polysaccharide capsule, not a polypeptide capsule.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: S. aureus can cause cavitating pneumonia, especially after influenza infection. However, it is not an encapsulated bacterium.  
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: P. aeruginosa is a Gram-negative bacterium. This patient’s sputum culture is growing a Gram-positive organism.  
❌ Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
Incorrect: M. tuberculosis can lead to severe pulmonary disease. However, it is not an encapsulated bacterium.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful red bump on the left  leg. The patient was initially bitten by a mosquito, but over the past several days, the area became red, hot, and tender to touch. He is otherwise healthy and does not smoke, use alcohol, or consume illicit substances. On physical examination, a 2 cm x 2 cm area of erythema, warmth, and fluctuance is observed on the anterior left leg as demonstrated below:


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient has an area of fluctuance, warmth, and erythema on physical examination, which is most consistent with a simple skin abscess. The most common organism implicated in skin abscesses is Staphylococcus aureus.

Skin abscesses are a common clinical condition and are defined as a collection of pus from a walled-off infection within the dermis or subcutaneous space. In nearly all cases, the offending organism is either methicillin-sensitive or methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Staphylococcus aureus is able to produce coagulase, which enables the pathogen to form fibrin clots around itself and lead to abscess formation.

Clinically, skin abscesses are characterized as painful, fluctuant, erythematous nodules, with or without surrounding cellulitis. Most skin abscesses resolve with simple incision and drainage and a course of antibiotic therapy.




Option Analysis

✅ Staphylococcus aureus :
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Streptococcus pyogenes:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pyogenes, also termed group A streptococcus, can cause a variety of skin conditions including non-bullous impetigo, erysipelas, and scarlet fever. However, Streptococcus pyogenes would not typically cause purulent infections or abscess formation.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is often implicated in skin and soft tissue infections. It is generally associated with infections in patients with a history of severe burn injuries, intravenous drug use, or diabetes mellitus. This patient has none of the aforementioned risk factors, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a rare cause of skin abscesses in the general population.
❌ Clostridium perfringens:
Incorrect:Clostridium perfringens is often implicated in myonecrosis and gas gangrene; it is not a common organism found in simple abscesses.
❌ Streptococcus viridans:
Incorrect: Streptococcus viridans is part of the normal skin flora and does not typically cause abscess formation. Streptococcus viridans, however, is implicated in dental caries, endocarditis, and infection of prosthetic joints.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a rash on the right forearm. The patient was recently admitted to the hospital for pain-control in the setting of nephrolithiasis. He recalls, “After I left, I was feeling fine, then the next day my arm started hurting, and I noticed a red rash near the site where I had my IV.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications daily. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 119/77 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a well demarcated erythematous, warm, and painful rash over the anterior aspect of the right forearm without fluctuance. Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s cutaneous findings?
questions.solution:
This otherwise healthy patient presents with a well-demarcated region of warmth, erythema, and swelling in the area of a recent intravenous line placement. Given the absence of fluctuance on physical examination, this patient’s clinical presentation is most consistent with a non-purulent cellulitis, which is most commonly caused by group A streptococcus (also termed Streptococcus pyogenes).

Cellulitis refers to an acute, painful infection of the deeper dermis and subcutaneous tissues. It is divided into purulent and non-purulent forms. Purulent cellulitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and is characterized by an area of warmth and pain with the presence of fluctuant nodules. In contrast, non-purulent cellulitis is most commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and is characterized by an area of warmth, erythema, and pain without fluctuant nodules.

Risk factors for developing cellulitis include skin barrier disruption (e.g., trauma, insect bite, IV placement), obesity, and venous stasis. Most patients are treated with a course of antibiotics that cover Gram positive organisms.




Option Analysis

✅ Group A streptococcus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Staphylococcus aureus :
Incorrect: Staphylococcus aureus is a well established cause of purulent cellulitis. However, this patient’s clinical presentation is more consistent with non-purulent cellulitis given the absence of fluctuant nodules.
❌ Pasteurella multocida:
Incorrect: Pasteurella multocida is a commonly implicated organism in skin and soft tissue injuries due to a dog or cat bite. In contrast, this patient has no history of recent animal bites.
❌ Trichophyton rubrum:
Incorrect:Trichophyton rubrum is a fungus that can cause tinea cruris, tinea pedis, and onychomycosis. However, these infections are superficial and would not manifest with systemic symptoms such as fever or tachycardia.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is often implicated in skin and soft tissue infections. It is generally associated with infections in patients with a history of severe burn injuries, intravenous drug use, or diabetes mellitus. This patient has none of the aforementioned risk factors, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a rare cause of cellulitis in the general population.

questions.text: An 8-month-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of a rash. It started 2 days ago on the neck and trunk and then spread to the face and extremities. The patient had an emergency department visit 3 days ago because of a generalized-tonic clonic seizure. At that time, he had a temperature of 40°C (104°F). Today, temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 30/min and blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Physical examination shows a blanching maculopapular rash that is most prominent on the neck, trunk, and buttocks.  A virus from which of the following classes is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a history of febrile seizure, followed by appearance of maculopapular rash and resolution of fever, is consistent with roseola infantum (exanthem subitum), which is caused by Human Herpesvirus-6 (HHV-6). It belongs to the herpes virus family, which are enveloped, double-stranded, and linear DNA viruses.  

HHV-6 is most likely transmitted by asymptomatic shedding of virus in secretions of close contacts, though most cases occur sporadically without a known exposure. The typical presentation of roseola infantum involves a prodrome characterized by a 3-5 day history of high fever often exceeding 40°C (104°F) in a child 6 months to 3 years of age. During the febrile phase, other manifestations include febrile seizures, rhinorrhea, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and Nagayama spots (small red spots on soft palate and uvula). After the fever abates, the typical exanthem appears that is characterized by blanching erythematous macules and papules on the neck and trunk first, which then spread to the face and extremities. The rash usually lasts for 1 to 2 days, but sometimes it may go away within as little as 2 to 4 hours. The diagnosis is based on clinical findings, and the infection is typically benign and self-limited.


Option Analysis

❌ Togavirus:
Incorrect: Rubella (which belongs to the togavirus class) is a single-stranded RNA virus that causes a maculopapular rash that spreads in a cephalo-caudal direction. Patients usually have a low-grade fever with the rash. Conversely, the appearance of a maculopapular rash after the resolution of fever is typical of roseola (Herpesvirus-6). 
❌ Reovirus:
Incorrect: A coltivirus in the Reovirus family can cause Colorado tick fever. It typically occurs in the Rocky Mountain states and is characterized by fever, myalgias, vomiting and weakness. A petechial or maculopapular rash is only observed in 15 percent of the patients. 
✅ Herpesvirus:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Calicivirus:
Incorrect: Norovirus in the Calicivirus family is the most common cause of gastroenteritis. A maculopapular rash is not usually seen.
❌ Parvovirus:
Incorrect: Parvovirus B19 is responsible for erythema infectiosum (fifth disease). In children, it typically presents with a “slapped cheek” rash, followed by the appearance of a lacy rash on the trunk and extremities. Appearance of a maculopapular rash after the resolution of fever is typical of roseola (Herpesvirus-6).

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with pain and discoloration of the right thigh. A week ago the patient was involved in a motor vehicle accident and suffered deep lacerations over the same region. The patient was evaluated at an urgent care facility afterward and a piece of scrap metal was removed from the right thigh. Currently, temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 108/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 70/44 mmHg and SpO2 is 93% of room air. The appearance of the right thigh is shown below. On palpation of the right thigh, there is tenderness and crepitus. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for this patient’s presentation?
 

 Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient with erythema, purple-black discoloration, bullae, and crepitus in the thigh most likely has gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Clostridium perfringens produces an exotoxin known as alpha-toxin, or phospholipase/lecithinase, which breaks down phospholipids in cell membranes and leads to tissue necrosis. Soft tissue inoculation of C. perfringens is classically associated with trauma through the skin.

Symptoms of myonecrosis (muscle breakdown from this toxin) are extreme pain and swelling, and sometimes a thin, watery purulent leakage from the wound.  Crepitus is a classic sign of this and is due to gas buildup in the tissue.

The fast-moving infection and massive tissue destruction causes fever and tachycardia, and can quickly progress to shock (like this patient), and eventually death - within just a few hours.

Treatment of clostridial myonecrosis requires prompt and complete surgical excision of the necrotic tissue. This can sometimes include amputation of an affected extremity. Individuals typically need supportive care to help manage fluids and maintain their hemodynamic status. High-dose and often broad-spectrum antibiotic treatment is required. Sometimes hyperbaric oxygen is used.  


Option Analysis

❌ Tetanospasmin:
Incorrect: Tetanospasmin is the exotoxin causing tetanus. The underlying pathogen is Clostridium tetani. Patients can present with spastic paralysis, trismus (lockjaw), risus sardonicus (raised eyebrows and open grin), and opisthotonos (spasms of spinal extensors).  
✅ Alpha toxin:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Erythrogenic toxin:
Incorrect: Erythrogenic toxin is responsible for scarlet fever caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. Typical presentations include blanching, sandpaper-like body rash, strawberry tongue, and circumoral pallor in the setting of group A streptococcal pharyngitis.  
❌ Tracheal cytotoxin:
Incorrect: Tracheal cytotoxin is one of the three toxins released by Bordetella pertussis. It causes whooping cough followed by post-tussive vomiting.  
❌ Shiga toxin:
Incorrect: Shiga toxin is an enterotoxin produced by Shigella. It causes crampy abdominal pain followed by tenesmus and bloody mucoid stools.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old man presents to a rural clinic in Southeast Asia for evaluation of lower extremity swelling. The symptoms developed around a year ago and have progressively worsened. Physical examination reveals findings similar to those shown in the image below. Which of the following pathogens is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
Wuchereria bancrofti is a parasitic roundworm that is the primary cause of lymphatic filariasis, also termed elephantiasis. The pathogen is transmitted via the bite of a female mosquito and is endemic in Sub-Saharan Africa, India, Southeast Asia, and the Pacific Islands.

After transmission, W. bancrofti invades the lymph nodes. This process can take nine months to a year to occur and leads to inflammation and eventual blockage of the lymphatic vessels. These changes can lead to severe lymphedema and swelling of the affected extremities as well as the formation of hydroceles.

Option Analysis

❌ Trichinella spiralis:
Incorrect: Trichinella spiralis is transmitted via the consumption of undercooked pork. The pathogen can cause myalgias, muscle weakness, as well as ocular edema, and hemorrhage. However, T. spiralis would not cause the lymphedema shown in the above image.  
❌ Clonorchis sinensis:
Incorrect: Clonorchis sinensis, also known as the liver fluke, can lead to biliary tract inflammation. Infected individuals are at increased risk for pigmented gallstones and cholangiocarcinoma. However, C. sinensis does not typically cause lower extremity swelling or lymphedema.  
✅ Wuchereria bancrofti:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sporothrix schenckii:
Incorrect: Sporothrix schenckii can manifest with cutaneous symptoms including nodules, pustules, and  ulcerations. However, the pathogen would not typically cause the diffuse extremity swelling noted in the above image.  
❌ Trypanosoma cruzi:
Incorrect: Trypanosoma cruzi causes Chagas disease and can manifest as dilated cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus, and megacolon. The pathogen is found mainly in South America, as opposed to Southeast Asia. Furthermore, T. cruzi does not typically present with diffuse extremity swelling and lymphedema.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the hospital with four days of erythema, pain, and swelling of the right leg. The patient's medical history includes hypertension and major depressive disorder. Current medications include carvedilol and fluoxetine. Medication allergies include doxycycline, penicillin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Temperature is 100.4 ºF (38 ºC), heart rate is 110 bpm, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 138/79 mmHg. On physical examination, there is erythema, swelling, and tenderness of the right leg extending from a 2 cm wound at the lateral malleolus up to the tibial plateau. Wound culture is positive for methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is treated with intravenous vancomycin and is transitioned to oral linezolid on the day of discharge. He is counseled on risks and possible side effects of this medication. Which of the following side effects may occur due to drug-drug interactions?
questions.solution:
This patient on fluoxetine has evidence of right leg cellulitis and a wound infected with methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA). Several oral antibiotics can be used to treat MRSA, such as doxycycline, linezolid and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Linezolid works well against gram-positive bacteria (including MRSA); however, linezolid also has weak monoamine oxidase inhibitory (MAOI) activity. For this reason, linezolid can increase levels of norepinephrine and serotonin, which can lead to serotonin syndrome.  

Serotonin syndrome is due to abnormally high levels of serotonin, and generally occurs in patients taking multiple serotonergic medications (e.g., linezolid, MAOI, SNRI, SSRI). It is a clinical diagnosis and often manifests with agitation, clonus, hyperreflexia and hyperthermia. Other clinical manifestations include diaphoresis, dry mucous membranes, and overactive bowels. Treatment is centered on stopping the offending medication and providing supportive care.  

Option Analysis

✅ Agitation and hyperreflexia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Bradykinesia and micrographia:
Incorrect: These are features that can be seen with drug-induced Parkinsonism or Parkinson disease. Linezolid does not cause Parkinsonism.
❌ Involuntary mouth movements:
Incorrect: Tardive dyskinesia can result from overuse or use of multiple anti-dopaminergic medications.
❌ Muscle breakdown:
Incorrect: Rhabdomyolysis has been rarely associated with daptomycin, an intravenous agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with rhabdomyolysis.
❌ Sunburn:
Incorrect: Photosensitivity can occur in patients taking doxycycline, another agent that can be used to treat methicillin-resistant S. aureus. Linezolid is not associated with severe/more frequent sunburns (photosensitivity).

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic for treatment of a pruritic and blistering rash on the legs, which developed around two days ago. He has been using over-the-counter ointments without relief. He recently went camping and thinks he may have been exposed to poison ivy. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, there are multiple bullae in a linear distribution on a bright red erythematous base on the bilateral shins. The patient is prescribed a 3-week oral prednisone taper to manage his symptoms. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to treat allergic contact dermatitis caused by point ivy. Among the answer choices, only sleep disturbance is associated with glucocorticoid therapy.    

Glucocorticoids are pharmacologically similar to endogenous cortisol. They are often used for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects. Glucocorticoids can treat conditions including Addison disease, allergic reactions, autoimmune diseases, chronic inflammatory diseases, and asthma.    

Glucocorticoids exert physiologic effects on multiple organ systems and thus have a wide range of side effects, as detailed in the following table:  



Option Analysis

✅ Sleep disturbance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with hyperglycemia and an increased risk of diabetes mellitus. This side effect is due to increased gluconeogenesis and insulin resistance.
❌ Leukopenia:
Incorrect: While glucocorticoids use is associated with a decreased lymphocyte, eosinophil, monocyte, and basophil count, the medication also leads to demargination of white blood cells (primarily neutrophils) from the blood vessel walls. These changes ultimately result in an artificially elevated white blood cell count on laboratory testing.
❌ Weight loss:
