Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with dose- and duration-dependent weight gain. This side effect is due to numerous contributing factors, including increased edema and metabolic changes.
❌ Hypotension:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are associated with hypertension. This side effect usually occurs at higher doses due to the upregulation of α1-adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of painful swelling and erythema on his right leg. The patient reports that he suffered minor cuts a few days ago while he was cleaning his garage. A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an indurated lesion surrounded by minor lacerations which are draining a purulent exudate. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 14,000 /mm3. Empiric antibiotic treatment is started after obtaining a sample of discharge for culture and sensitivity. Results of the culture reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of resistance to methicillin in this bacteria?

choices.text: Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps
Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painful erythematous swelling on right leg draining purulent exudate is most likely suffering from cellulitis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin is consistent with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.  

Resistance to methicillin and other β-lactams is due to one of the following mechanisms: 
  • Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) altering its affinity for β-lactams (basis of methicillin resistance in staphylococci and of penicillin resistance in pneumococci and most resistant enterococci) 
  •  Inactivation of antibiotics by β-lactamase (penicillinases) is the most common mechanism of resistance of  staphylococci and many Gram-negative organisms 
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs, which is only in Gram-negative species because of the impermeable outer membrane of their cell wall 
  •  Efflux pump that efficiently transports some β-lactam antibiotics from the periplasm back across the cell wall outer membrane

Option Analysis

❌ Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps:
Incorrect: Decreased uptake or Increased efflux of the drug out of bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps is the mechanism of resistance of tetracyclines.
❌ Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase.
✅ Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.
❌ Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, which is the normal binding site for vancomycin, to D-alanine-D-lactate, to which the drug does not bind.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department with discharge from an ulcer on the left foot. He has had the ulcer for nearly a year. However, the ulcer started giving off copious white discharge over the past few days. There has also been some pain and increasing redness around the area. Past medical history is significant for poorly-controlled type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin and insulin. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), blood pressure is 117/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination reveals a well-demarcated ulcer with a tender erythematous border and a sizeable purulent discharge on the left foot. Foot radiography does not show evidence of osteomyelitis. Wound cultures grow methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Blood cultures are negative. He is started on vancomycin and linezolid but fails to show improvement. He is subsequently started on tigecycline. What is the most likely adverse effect this patient will experience with tigecycline?
questions.solution:
Tigecycline antibiotics are tetracycline derivatives developed to overcome traditional tetracycline resistance. Tigecycline can treat multidrug-resistant bacteria such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. It binds to the 30S bacterial ribosomal subunit to inhibit protein synthesis.

Its side effects are similar to tetracycline antibiotics and include nausea and vomiting, headache, photosensitivity, and tooth discoloration. Moreover, there has been an increased risk of death associated with tigecycline use. As a result, it should only be used when there are no alternative treatments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Nausea and vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral motor neuropathy:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with dapsone therapy. This antibiotic inhibits dihydropteroate synthase and is used to treat leprosy and Pneumocystis jiroveci prophylaxis.  
❌ Orange discoloration of urine:
Incorrect: This adverse effect can be seen with rifampin therapy. The drug inhibits DNA-dependent RNA polymerase and is used for tuberculosis and leprosy treatment.  
❌ Vitamin B6 deficiency:
Incorrect: Vitamin B6 deficiency is a significant adverse effect caused by isoniazid. The drug inhibits the synthesis of mycolic acids and is used to treat tuberculosis. Isoniazid should be administered with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) to prevent peripheral neuropathy and sideroblastic anemia.  
❌ Disulfiram-like reaction:
Incorrect: This side effect is most commonly seen with drugs such as metronidazole, griseofulvin, sulfonylureas, procarbazine, and certain cephalosporins are taken with alcohol. A disulfiram-like reaction can present with severe flushing, tachycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the clinic for increasing redness and pain at a surgery site on the left arm. He had a skin excision performed about one week ago to treat squamous cell carcinoma. The redness developed two days later and, since then, has been spreading. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and dyspepsia. Current medications include calcium carbonate, metformin, hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, and aspirin. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 109/74 mmHg, pulse is 81/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. There is bright red erythema surrounding the excision site with purulent drainage and tenderness to light palpation on physical examination. A bacterial culture of the excision site grows methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus. The patient is started on a 7-day course of doxycycline. Which of the following medications should not be taken concurrently with doxycycline?
questions.solution:
This patient should avoid concurrently consuming doxycycline and calcium carbonate. This precaution should be taken since the divalent calcium ions can inhibit the absorption of tetracyclines in the gut and decrease the drug’s efficacy. Tetracyclines should not be taken with milk, antacids, or iron-containing preparations.

Moreover, tetracyclines can accumulate in the teeth and bones, causing discoloration of the teeth and inhibition of bone growth. As a result, they are contraindicated in pregnancy, women who are breastfeeding, and children less than 8-years-old.  

Option Analysis

✅ Calcium carbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and metformin. Metformin can cause lactic acidosis and should be used with caution in patients with renal failure.  
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and hydrochlorothiazide. Hydrochlorothiazide is a sulfa derivative, so it should not be given to patients with sulfa allergies.  
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and lisinopril. There is a high risk of acute kidney injury and hyperkalemia when taken together. Lisinopril should not be taken with aliskiren, a direct renin inhibitor.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: There is no interaction between doxycycline and aspirin. Aspirin should not be given to children, especially in viral infection, as it may lead to Reye syndrome.
